title: Michio Ashikaga
text:
is a former <a href="Japanese%20people">Japanese</a> <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Ashikaga was born in <a href="Akita%20Prefecture">Akita Prefecture</a> on May 22, 1950. After graduating from high school, he joined <a href="Urawa%20Reds">Mitsubishi Motors</a> in 1969. The club won the league champions in <a href="1969%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">1969</a>, <a href="1973%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">1973</a> and <a href="1978%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">1978</a>. The club also won <a href="1971%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1971</a>, <a href="1973%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1973</a>, <a href="1978%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1978 Emperor's Cup</a> and <a href="1978%20JSL%20Cup">1978 JSL Cup</a>. He retired in 1978. He played 132 games and scored 36 goals in the league.
National team career.
In September 1971, Ashikaga was selected <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> for <a href="Football%20at%20the%201972%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20qualification">1972 Summer Olympics qualification</a>. At this qualification, on September 23, he debuted against <a href="Malaysia%20national%20football%20team">Malaysia</a>. He also played at <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28AFC%20and%20OFC%29">1974 World Cup qualification</a>. He played 7 games for Japan until 1975.
